asl.name: Discussion
asl.description: Discussion based learning is an interactive approach to education that focuses on active student participation through group discussions and debates. This method requires students to express their views, share perspectives and take part in critical thinking instead of following lectures alone. The students learn how to listen, express their opinions and think about the diversity of views, thereby creating an active and constructive learning environment which is more than just lecture based methods.

citation.title: Discussion Models in Seamless Online Learning Integrated Discussion (SOLID) Environment: Selection vs. Performance
citation.conference: IEEE 12th International Conference on Advanced Learning Technologies

sources.summary: In the study, 41 college students in the field of child and infant care participated in problem solving and project discussions using SOLID. They preferred asynchronous discussions (M2) over synchronous (M1) or mixed (M3) formats for problem-solving activities. For project-based activities, all groups used asynchronous (M2) or mixed discussions (M3).  Quality-wise, mixed discussions (M3) performed better than asynchronous ones (M2), suggesting that combining synchronous and asynchronous elements improved discussion outcomes.

citation.title: Identifying consistent patterns of quality learning discussions in blended learning

sources.summary: The study analysed the influence ofblended discussions on education among postgraduates, finding differences in educational quality. Deep discussion approaches and higher academic performance correlated positively with coherent learning concepts in discussions. The course evaluations have been closely interconnected with the internet discussions, which offer specific advantages.  The results showed a positive correlation between cohesive concepts and deep approaches, while fragmented concepts and surface approaches showed a negative correlation in both face to face and online discussions.

citation.title: Do online discussion groups enhance students’ analytical ability and recall of factual knowledge?

sources.summary: For two parts of the World Politics course, using internet discussion groups and without ODGs, the study compares 2 sections to see if they have any difference. While participation in ODG correlated to higher overall GPA, there were no significant differences of factual recall or analytical performance between ODG and non ODG sections. These results could have been affected by factors such as group size and measurement techniques.

citation.title: Online discussion, student engagement, and critical thinking

sources.summary: Students used ANGEL software for the online discussion in traditional undergraduate courses. Divided into three groups per course, some discussions were moderated, while others were not. The level of participation and substantial replies was encouraged, with the awarding of points. The study examined 361 posts, looking at the interaction and critical thinking dimensions. The findings show that, although student characteristics such as course levels, GPAs and gender have no correlation with critical thinking, there has been an increased interaction in discussions associated with larger level of critical thinking.

citation.title: Impact of combination of short lecture and group discussion on the learning of physiology by nonmajor undergraduates

sources.summary: The impact of group discussions on a nongradual college student learning mammalian physiology was assessed in the study. Participation of students and an improved understanding of physiology in all grade levels have been enhanced through the integration of traditional lectures with group discussions. These findings support the development of studentcentered learning, highlight the effectiveness of combining lectures and group discussion for students who do not major in physiology.

citation.title: Teaching Students to Engage with Evidence: An Evaluation of Structured Writing and Classroom Discussion Strategies

sources.summary: The study compared group discussions and structured-writing exercises in first-year writing seminars using a political science article. Group discussions have proven to be more effective and have enhanced the summarization and evaluation of students' evidence. Both methods have reinforced the importance of active learning, in particular group discussions, when it comes to smaller classroom settings, with regard to both understanding and evaluating critically.

citation.title: Student Responsible Learning: Getting students to read online discussions

sources.summary: To promote critical thinking, A Thematic Analysis Assignment (TAA) was introduced to two senior level courses with the focus on Ervin Goffman's 'Stigma.' Survey responses from students showed strong engagement, with 86.7% acknowledging the assignment's benefits for learning. It made it easier for colleagues to interact and create a positive learning environment. The deadline was a problem for some students. Overall, the TAA has effectively promoted active learning and peer interaction while suggesting only minor modifications for future use.

citation.title: The use of the discussion method at University: Enhancement of Teaching and learning

sources.summary: In large classes at university, discussion is an effective method of teaching which requires highly qualified teachers to be in charge. The students, who were surveyed using the Likert scale, preferred to debate rather than lecture. This approach strengthens language skills, cognition and individual development to promote an educational environment conducive to learning. Discussions can give students an opportunity to express themselves, defend and shape their opinion, which benefits both academics and society in general.

citation.title: Effect of active learning and online discussions on the academic performances of dental students

sources.summary: The study focused on dental students studying law, assessing the effect of discussions in online and offline health professions courses. A total of 114 participants were tested for the Criminal Procedure Code in four online and two offline groups. In particular, the online Self Study and Discussion Group performed very well in spite of an even better score for the offline equivalent. There were no significant differences between online and offline verbatim groups when it came to item scores. However, the offline seminar and discussion group scored higher in transfer item scores. In summary, this study supports the effectiveness of self-studies and discussion in online courses for students who are studying to be dentists.

citation.title: Using wiki-based discussion forums in calculus: E-pathway toward improving students’ retention and learning in STEM gateway courses (Minority serving two-year college settings)

sources.summary: The study used mixed methods to analyse the impact of Piazza, a virtual discussion platform, based on data from two semesters. Over time, students' participation increased and fostered a collaborative learning environment in which students actively supported each other. The report found that students' attitudes towards learning were affected positively by retention, achievement in a course of study and their attitude to education. In addition, students felt that the Platform's usefulness as well as its capacity to promote a sense of connection were positive.

citation.title: Learning through discussions: Comparing the benefits of Small-Group and Large-Class settings

sources.summary: The study compared discussions in an upper level course of political theory to complete class and small group discussion. Both formats had a positive impact on student engagement and satisfaction, according to feedback from 146 questionnaires. Critical thinking and inclusiveness, which benefits from a diverse range of student backgrounds as well as achievements, have in particular benefited from the smaller groups discussions. The integration of discussions, i.e. small group meetings, can provide a significant enhancement in educational outcomes and overall level of student satisfaction for lecture classes.

citation.title: Does Active Learning Enhance Learner Outcomes? Evidence from Discussion Participation in Online Classes

sources.summary: In a Latin American Politics course, 42 students engaged in module-based discussions. The study took into account the level of participation and classified them according to their engagement, thereby creating an active learning index. The findings showed that active learning in the field of discussions was associated with higher GPAs. In addition, women tended to engage in a more active manner compared with men. Lower GPA students' course performance has been significantly enhanced by the reading of peer posts, although this effect is diminishing as grade points are increased. In general, there was a correlation between improved grades and more active participation.

citation.title: Using Discussion Forums to Improve Student Retention Rate: Our Experience with Certificate in Information Technology (CIT) Program
citation.conference: IEEE 14th International Conference on Advanced Learning Technologies

sources.summary: In order to encourage students' interaction and support, EnhanceEdu interventions in rural technical colleges also included debate forums and a newsletter. In spite of low initial participation, strategies such as sample questions increased engagement, increased the number of assignments submitted, and increased the retention rate, by 97%. Active involvement in forums, highlighting their positive effects on student performance and building a supportive college community has been significantly correlated to higher final grades of 85%.

citation.title: Let’s debate: Active learning encourages student participation and critical thinking

sources.summary: This article highlights the incorporation of structured debates as a fundamental part of a politics course. The approach focuses on critical thinking through early debates and teaching of related skills over time. In order to improve critical thinking further, cooperative tools and simulations are used. Pointed questions, involving more students, are added to the discussion after the debate. The format of the debate is very popular within students, which encourages more substantive discussion, increasing participation, improving critical thinking and writing skills.

citation.title: Learning through debate during problem-based learning: an active learning strategy

sources.summary: Second year female medical students participated in debates in which they were divided into proposition and opposition groups during 2014-2016. The outcomes showed significant benefits: the debate has helped to strengthen fundamental thinking, an exposure to controversial issues, skills in making arguments, interpretation and analysis of evidence. Furthermore, the meetings had a beneficial impact on communication, negotiation capacity, time management and confidence in expression of ideas.

citation.title: Engaging Engineering Students in Active Learning and Critical Thinking through Class Debates

sources.summary: Students from the engineering school with strong mathematics and physics skills are exposed to a wide range of text heavy courses requiring innovative teaching methods. Active learning, including debates, has been implemented in the study and is leading to higher grades. The learning targets of the course have been successfully achieved by most students. The use of debates has had a positive impact on attracting students to study in the engineering field, increasing critical thinking and enhancing academic results.

citation.title: Teaching Tip: Active Learning Using Debates in an IT Strategy Course

sources.summary: A study has shown that debates in an IT strategy course are beneficial for learning and enjoyment. Six weeks of preparation, research on audiences and specific assessment criteria were part of the debate format. The students' response has been positive and they see the relevance of working IT professionals. Debates, including technically focused ones like programming or database development, could be used in ISIT courses.

citation.title: The power of in-class debates

sources.summary: Debates stimulate active participation and content mastery, while fostering critical thinking skills. Knowledge and opinions are strongly influenced by the involvement of students in debates. Class debate becomes a very powerful tool of teaching, which can be used for different disciplines.

citation.title: Increasing student involvement and learning through using debate as an assessment

sources.summary: The importance of interaction between teachers and learners is important for education. Debates help to raise awareness of important issues, which in turn helps to stimulate divergent thinking. They call on students to actively engage in the learning process, promote diversity of perspective and take responsibility for their understanding. Debates help to facilitate discussions across large groups, increase personal knowledge and critical understanding.

citation.title: The use of debates as an active learning tool in a college of pharmacy healthcare delivery course
citation.journal: Currents in Pharmacy Teaching and Learning

sources.summary: The article follows up on debates in the pharmacy healthcare delivery course as well as an appraisal of student attitudes and perceptions. The findings show that debates are able to engage students on controversial health issues effectively. The teams presented evidence, addressed questions and concluded the debate. Surveys show that debates based on active learning strategies and prior research in the field of medical education are of great value for the achievement of the course content.

citation.title: How active are students in online discussion forums?
citation.conference: Proceedings of the Thirteenth Australasian Computing Education Conference - Volume 114 (ACE '11)

sources.summary: The research focuses on the participation of online students in discussions, and its relation to grade levels. The findings show that there is a lack of engagement among the students. However, there was a correlation between high grades and consistent participation. This paper explores various factors impacting students' active online engagement.

citation.title: The effect of using online discussion forums on students’ learning

sources.summary: Communication and social skills are enhanced through online discussion forum (ODFs). Saudi students are fond of working together and value advice from their peers. There are mixed results in research on the link between participation of students in education funding schemes and learning outcomes, suggesting that situational factors may play a role. It appears that there is a relationship between traditional and ODF learning in terms of background knowledge. A higher grade point average has been obtained in experimental groups using ODFs, but some students have not completed their required tasks within these forums.

citation.title: Online discussion forums

sources.summary: The study is designed to examine the usage of internet discussion forums by young political science students. The results show that students are more willing to use student-centred methods of teaching. The grading contributions to the Board Discussion Forums were supported by most students. However, low confidence, shyness, fear of mistakes and intimidation are among the reasons for not participating.

citation.title: Outcomes of chat and discussion board use in online Learning: A research synthesis

sources.summary: For the integration of students in full Internet courses, interactive discussions and chat rooms are essential. Teacher facilitations has to influence student participation. In online courses, it is possible to enhance results for students by examining effective online dialogue and chat methods.

citation.title: Get them to read, get them to talk: Using discussion forums to enhance student learning

sources.summary: The Discussion Forum promotes student involvement through CMS, which is a crucial component of the course grade. While it is optional, it is important for grades and students are able to take part in it throughout the semester. Overall, the question is beneficial for students, but a minority of them think that it limits their peers' learning. In spite of minor problems, it has good management and is rare in facing technical difficulties which positively impact on learning outcomes for students.

citation.title: Through the lens of students: How online discussion forums affect students’ learning
citation.journal: International Journal of Technology in Education (IJTE)

sources.summary: The study has examined the perspectives of 13 students on online discussion forums 'ODFs' in a virtual English language course at Sultan Qaboos University, Oman. ODFs were largely welcomed by participants, with improvements in critical skills, engagement and community interaction cited as reasons for this. The structured discussions were described as 'interesting', 'effective' and 'very useful'. The study focused on the effect of discussion structure on perception and student participation in high order thinking. Increased mental, emotional and cognitive engagement has also been observed.

citation.title: Online Discussion Forum as a tool for interactive learning and communication
citation.journal: International Journal of Recent Technology and Engineering

sources.summary: The technologies have a profound effect on student learning. Participation and learning are enhanced by online discussion forums, which can be used in conjunction with lectures. The computer helps to achieve objectives in education. These forums encourage constructive debate, support cooperation and transform the teacher's role into a facilitator. The right use of the digital learning system is key, even though student attitudes and their misuse can affect results.

citation.title: Revisiting the Socratic method of teaching to improve third-year pharmacy students' critical thinking and advanced pharmacy practice experience readiness in a critical care elective
citation.journal: Currents in Pharmacy Teaching and Learning

sources.summary: The purpose of the study was to enhance pharmacy students' critical thinking, clinical reasoning and APPE training through a Socratic education method in an elective paediatrics course. The results show a significant increase in critical thinking, clinical reasoning and preparedness of students for APPE. In particular, they demonstrated significant improvements in the HSRT reasoning test score, increased positive APPE readiness survey results, and more favourable teaching style ratings than that of traditional courses. Overall, the Socratic method is highly effective in attracting students and providing significant improvements over a short period of time.

citation.title: Thesis on motivation towards learning perceived in Socratic seminar versus traditional lecture

sources.summary: The study found that, contrary to the initial expectations, Socratic Seminars had a more positive influence on certain aspects of teaching than traditional lectures. This implies a need for an equitable approach to training that incorporates both methods. The wider point is that diversity of teaching strategies, demonstrating the importance of using various approaches to learning, has a different effect on student motivation and has to be chosen wisely.

citation.title: Critical Thinking and Values Clarification through Socratic Seminars

sources.summary: This article examines the effectiveness of Socratic seminars through qualitative research. The study took into consideration student involvement, focus groups and interviews with teachers and students. Results show that seminars support higher-order thinking, effective strategies for conflict resolution and increased interest in learning. Seminars on relevant and actual subjects have been highly praised, with those involving metaphoric learning situations considered less important.

citation.title: Socratic Seminar with Data: A Strategy to Support Student Discourse and Understanding

sources.summary: The article explores how Socratic seminar can be adapted to engage students with data, leading to improved understanding and collaborative meaning-making. It focuses on a case study in a high school type 2 diabetes curriculum, where students analyzed complex data from the Diabetes Prevention Program study. The seminar format encouraged students to reason through the data together, fostering deeper comprehension and discussions about the implications of the findings. Teachers have found that the use of a Socratic seminar with data has helped to uncover student misunderstandings and has provided insight into their understanding of scientific concepts. The method has been used to promote student-led debates, thoughtful analysis and reflection on personal links in the subject. Teachers were able to improve the learning of students and their engagement with scientific data through specific questioning methods and debriefing sessions.
